steps.description: 1. Find the visual divider: locate the continuous horizontal black band that runs across the whole canvas and the continuous vertical black band that runs top‑to‑bottom. These two perpendicular bands are the reference cross that splits the image into four quadrants.
2. Identify the lower‑left quadrant: it is the square region that lies below the horizontal band and to the left of the vertical band (i.e., the block immediately southwest of the cross).

3. Measure the quadrant size by counting contiguous non‑cross columns to the left of the vertical band and non‑cross rows below the horizontal band. That count N gives the output grid dimensions N×N (in this example N = 10).
4. Extract the entire N×N block: copy every cell inside that lower‑left quadrant exactly (preserve colors/values and relative positions). Do not alter or include any pixels that belong to the cross.

5. Place the copied block at the origin of the output grid (top‑left of the new image), producing an N×N output. The output size is inferred from the measured quadrant size and will always be the contiguous region bounded by the cross on its top and right sides.
